instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1534: What is A1534? A1534 is a model number for a 12 inch size Macbook  from years 2015, 2016 with EMC 2746, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00045, 820-00244..
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.820-00045: What is 820-00045? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3R3V0_AON: What is PP3V3R3V0_AON? PP3V3R3V0_AON is the first power rail you need to get a USB-C charger to go from 5v to 20v on an A1534 Macbook with an 820-00045 board..

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Hello,

I have an <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> that had water damages, and has been ultra-sonic cleaned in other store.
Now it doesn't power on.

It has 4.98V on charger and pulls 0.02A.

In <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> i have 0V and on F4700 i have 5V.

Can you help me?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Ultrasonic cleaner can make more damage, if not correctly used.
Sweep function is a must, to avoid hot spots in the process.
Check for knocked off components and broken traces.

Be sure no short on any power rail.

Can we know what board do you have?
Is a must when ask for help.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Sorry, the board is an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00045</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>.
I can't see any broken traces, but It seams that i have a missing SW6900, and the <CHIP>U4490</CHIP>.
I have a short in <SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL> and in <SIGNAL>E85LSMUX_RFU_EN_L</SIGNAL> i have 0.99 ohm resistance

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
<CHIP>U4700</CHIP>/80 are the first suspects there.
But more chips are connected on <SIGNAL>3V3_AON</SIGNAL>.

Short on  <SIGNAL>E85LSMUX_RFU_EN_L</SIGNAL>  points more to <CHIP>U4470</CHIP>/90.
Pray that is not <CHIP>U4600</CHIP>...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Hello again.
It seams that the <CHIP>U4600</CHIP> is shorted. It is the only thing that gets hoted when injected 2.5V with 3A in  <SIGNAL>3V3_AON</SIGNAL> (already taked out the  <CHIP>U4700</CHIP>/80 )
Is it possible to replace the <CHIP>U4600</CHIP>?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Change it with same from donor board...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message: OK. IÂ´ve changed the <CHIP>U4600</CHIP>, and reballed the  <CHIP>U4700</CHIP>/80. The shorts are gone ( <SIGNAL>3V3_AON</SIGNAL>  and  <SIGNAL>E85LSMUX_RFU_EN_L</SIGNAL> ) but still no boot ( It has 4.98V on charger and pulls 0.02 A).

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message: Post diode mode to ground ar <SIGNAL>3V3_AON</SIGNAL>; red probe connected to ground and viceversa.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Hello,
red probe connected to ground  = 0.341V
black probe connected to ground = 0.859V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Other chips from <SIGNAL>3V3_AON</SIGNAL> can be damaged.
Even there is no short anymore.
0.341 still looks low; <CHIP>U4700</CHIP> is the first suspect...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message: On pad 1of the board, of the <CHIP>U4700</CHIP> i have 0.339 but all other pins are arround 0.500 / 600. this maybe means that the problem is before the <CHIP>U4700</CHIP>, don't you think? Am i understanding this wrong?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message: OK, replaced the <CHIP>U4700</CHIP> (from donor board) but the behavior is the same (0.320V)

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Still other chip with problems on <SIGNAL>3V3_AON</SIGNAL>.
Try <CHIP>U4780</CHIP> now...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Hello again,
I've replaced <CHIP>U4780</CHIP> and now thr  <SIGNAL>3V3_AON</SIGNAL>  its also 0.331 in diode reading, but It is pulling 19.5V but only consumes 0.2A on ampmeter

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Diode mode should be higher than 0.400 I think.
Compare with working board.
Seems that still a bad chip on <SIGNAL>3V3_AON</SIGNAL>...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
I don't have any working board. Is there any other way?
On 2 other boards (parts) the value is near the same. In this board, on  <SIGNAL>3V3_AON</SIGNAL> i have 3.28V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
You've got 3V3 after changed <CHIP>U4600</CHIP>.
It was damaged by overvoltage on <SIGNAL>3V3_AON</SIGNAL>.
Something else must be affected, even not shorted to ground.

"<CHIP>U4700</CHIP> on the 12" <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> Retina Macbook from the year 2015 is SLG4AP645AV.
This is the most common cause of a 6-400 ohm low value on the <SIGNAL>PP3V3R3V0_AON</SIGNAL> power rail."
This is an old note from dukefawks; so even 400 is lower value than normal...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Good morning,

I've replace the <CHIP>U4700</CHIP> with a new one, but the same result. On <CHIP>U4700</CHIP> i have, on <SIGNAL>BBPD_RPD_EN</SIGNAL> (PIN 17) 3.2V and on <SIGNAL>BBPD_VCONN_EN</SIGNAL> 0V, but on <SIGNAL>BBPD_VCONN1_EN</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>BBPD_VCONN2_EN</SIGNAL>  (Pins 5 and 8) i have 0V.

Now i notated that the power cable only works in one position. If if flip the cable, it doesn' t work.

Is this relevant?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
This denotes a problem with CC1/2 lines.
If <CHIP>U4700</CHIP> is good for sure, then change <CHIP>U7860</CHIP>/65.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
I've replaced <CHIP>U7860</CHIP>/65 and the behaviour is the same. 
Diode readings on <CHIP>U4700</CHIP> of pin 10 is 0.530, and on pin 12 it is 0.546.
With power connected i have on pin10 0V and on pin 12 0.850V.

Is this helpless? do you think i should give up on it?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
Is not recommended to waste too much time on <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> boards anyway.
All of them end with dead CPU.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
OK, tanks.
Just for future knowleged, is there any way that i can make sure (at least probable) that it has a bad CPU? Can i mesure something to make sure, and avoid all this time and spare components use?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message:
As I said, this is not an exact science.
Every time you got <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> in the service, think if worth the time.
You can solve a power problem and customer can come back in few months with dead CPU/SSD, claiming for warranty.
Try to explain him your previous repair has nothing to do with new problem...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1534</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no power
threads.message: OK, Thank you
